# Draft:Egyptian invasions of horn of Africa

The Egyptian invasions of the Horn of Africa were a series of 19th-century military campaigns launched by the Khedivate of Egypt to expand southward into the Red Sea and East African regions. Seeking control over key trade routes and resources, Egyptian forces invaded territories now part of Sudan, Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Somalia.
Well-equipped with modern weaponry, the Egyptian army defeated numerous local powers, seizing strategic cities such as Kassala and Massawa. The invasions resulted in a decisive Egyptian victory â€” thousands of locals were enslaved or displaced, and large amounts of gold, ivory, and livestock were taken north.
The campaigns marked the height of Egyptian expansion under the Muhammad Ali dynasty, establishing Egypt as a dominant regional power until the late 19th century.
